title: Who do you consider to be the more iconic guitarist, Keith Richards or Eddie Van Halen? - Quora

response.answer_text: Note: I thought I was answering an question comparing Hendrix and Eddie Vanhalen - clearly I must have had a brain feeeze - however the comments below do actually answer the question. Apologies. I’ve left the answer up because its interesting anyway. :). Thanks. Stuart. This is not something you can really compare, but here goes: Hendrix did things with the guitar that nobody had ever seen before. Literally. Whilst Eddie brought finger tapping to the fore, he wasn’t the first to do it. Emit Brown, a jazz player was the first in 1969. Hendrix was a great player. Eddie can do everything that Hendrix could do and was a great player 15 year later. I can do everything both of them can do, but that’s nothing compared with the latest virtuosos now. There are 10 year old Chinese girls that are better technically than me. However, they have no musical touch. And thats the difference between people who learn feel for musicality and not. This begs the question as to what an iconic guitarist is. Is it necessarily technical ability (see 10 year olds being incredible guitarists on YouTube), or is it the ability to create and project emotion via your playing. After 42 years of playing, I have decided it’s the latter, though it must be tempered with the ability to be able to be technically good when necessary. Therefore, I choose Hendrix as the most iconic. He literally created the heavy rock/blues genre. But as for technical pre-neoclassical (non jazz) guitar virtuosos are concerned, two guitarists were responsible for that and Eddie was one of them. The other was the late Randy Rhodes. Of course you can’t forget the influence of amazing players like Gary Moore, who was playing serious rock/blues and jazz blues fusion in 1969 to 1976, blindingly fast and entirely responsible for the likes of Eddie et al. They were also iconic pioneers though they didn’t get the credit they should have. In short. Hendrix wins, as they all owe their styles to him.

First off Kudos for not finishing with “and why or why not” that drives me mental. And to caveat my answer, you’re asking for personal opinions: as such mine is likely to be at odds with most others, partly due to my own ignorance. For me, Eddie is the more iconic. Keith is an icon for sure but in my mind he’s more of a pop culture icon: the indestructable, immortal, immovable object to Chuck Norris’ unstoppable force.When I picture Eddie in my head I see him centre stage with those massive trousers and crazy guitar, shredding the shit out of it like the Rock icon he is. Even though I don’t know a huge amount of VH’s catalogue, I can ‘hear’ Eddie’s sound to accompany the picture in my head. When I picture Keith, I don’t hear guitar. Actually he’s not even holding a guitar. He’s staring down the camera into my soul with that tanned-leather sofa skin, crazy hair, ice cool, cigarette on the go. That might sound really disrespectful to one of the most influential members of influential bands in music history. It’s not supposed to be. I’m not trying to take away from his achievements. It’s just how I see the two of them.
